texts.definition: The level to which a game provides new challenges, learning opportunities, or experiences when played again.
markups: <style="Definition">The level to which a game provides new challenges, learning opportunities, or experiences when played again.</style>

Many games are designed to be played many times. In order for these to be interesting, the game must offer new challenges to players or give players new experiences that are perceived as entertaining enough to merit continued playing. The degree to which a game provides these incentives determines its level of <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> have so many possible outcomes that players have very little chance of ever playing two games which are exactly the same. This means that every game session will have new challenges in which players can test their skills.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> can be played many times due to having several different missions and randomizing enemies and challenges. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style> does it through letting players use different classes, in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> this is instead achieved through letting players personalize their characters through choices of abilities and skills. Players who have completed the levels of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal">Portal</link></style> can still find challenges in these by trying the challenge and advanced modes available.

Multiplayer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> allow players to choose a character class to play. This gives them special abilities, which means that beyond the normal differences in gameplay due to varieties in players and levels, players also have different possibilities of what to do and have different roles in their teams.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> provides certain <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> by allowing players to take on different roles through having different weapons than the other players. They provide more <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> through letting players team up against other player groups where the two available sides have radically different gameplay (and the infected team have very different abilities within the team).
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

An <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style> is a basic prerequisite for <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> but some general approaches to how <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> can be achieved exist: providing <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style> so players can have the goal of trying to play better next time, letting the challenges players meet differ between game instances, allowing the challenges to be solved in several different ways, or letting players compare results between different game instance through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>. Besides these strategies, <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style> provide local <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> within games and  allow players to do <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style>, but they have little effect, or negative effect, on <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> of the game as a whole.

Games that provide a huge potential game state space seldom offer players exactly the same challenges and thereby provide one form of <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>. Another is to use <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>. All but the most trivial uses of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> make gameplay challenges different, but this can become more explicit when it is used to create different <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> for every game instance (as for example is done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>). A slightly more limited version is to use <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-goals">Asymmetric Goals</link></style> (as for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style> or team versus team matches in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>), but this can be use together with other solutions to multiply the variety of challenged encountered (that is, most types of <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-gameplay">Asymmetric Gameplay</link></style> can be used to this effect). <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style> guarantee that different end states can exist, but how much this creates <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> depend heavily on how early these start diverting and how much they influence gameplay; <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> work similarly but guarantee the presence of choices rather than end states. <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> that are aware of players who have played the game before can change the setup of the particular game instances to provide new challenges. This can for example be achieved through <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> (quite often through <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style>); although games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style> can allow the players to reconfigure their <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> without the presence of <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> provides an example of this).

While varying the challenges in the ways mentioned above given <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>, this can also be achieved through letting players have different ways of trying to meet the challenges. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style> - and especially those providing <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> between game entities - are an easy way to support this but letting players complete the game or parts of the game in different ways can be done through providing them with a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style> (and is another way through which <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-gameplay">Asymmetric Gameplay</link></style> supports <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>). While this is typically done by providing players with different sets of actions but which are performed in the same medium, <style="Link"><link="player-avatar-proximity">Player-Avatar Proximity</link></style> shows how <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> can be achieved through offering players the opportunity through physical enacting gameplay actions or doing so through avatars. <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style> can provide some varieties as well since players can try to try and complete different set of them, or all or none of them, compared to earlier game instances. <style="Link"><link="easter-eggs">Easter Eggs</link></style> can offer the same type of options for players, as long as they are aware of them (e.g. through linking <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> to them). <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> lets players try to solve different types of sub-challenges to the overall challenges and therefore can provide <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> as long as players are willing to change roles between game instances or game sessions.

<style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> is often acquired through <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> by supporting players with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> to measure their level of successes with previous game instances, which can be their own or other players. For games that require player skill, <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> becomes automatic as players strive to achieve, test, and show <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. Similarly, games where players can make use of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> have a certain level of <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>, as players can develop this knowledge between game sessions to improve their gameplay (this assumes the co-presences of either <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style> since perfect <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> makes replaying a game pointless). While this can make players engage in <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>, the level with which <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> can be done before games can also modulate the <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>. <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style> can be used as a measure of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> in both <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, and allow the players to have a measure of their <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>, formalized to be measured by the game system (as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal">Portal's</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cogs">Cogs</link></style> time challenges do) or improvised by players, can perform the same function. <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>, with the exception of <style="Link"><link="polyathlons">Polyathlons</link></style>, also allow for a similar type of <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> as a game is typically played several times to create the outcome of the <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="near-miss-indicators">Near Miss Indicators</link></style> can show players how close they were to succeeding, encouraging them to try again and possibility also increasing their chances of succeeding by the information the provide.

<style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> can explicitly encouraged <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> already present through other patterns, for example to make players make use of different <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> or choosing different goals from a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style> (especially if they are <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style>); <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style> are in particular worth mentioning here since they can encourage players to first test different ways of playing before committing to them.

<style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> and those with <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style> do not in themselves provide <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> but they are often designed to function as such (e.g. through having <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style>), so this type of game may be considered if <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> is a high level design goal.

Games that are challenging or provide experiences based upon the lack of knowledge of players, i.e. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>, are difficult to combine with <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> if the information is not changed between the game instances. <style="Link"><link="quizzes">Quizzes</link></style> is an archetypical examples of this. The problem is is due to the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> players acquire when <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> of what happens in the game which can be used in later game instances. This information can affect <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> in many ways: <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> will no longer be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> will be less effective when players experience the same situations again, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> will become trivial if it is not changed between game instances, <style="Link"><link="unknown-goals">Unknown Goals</link></style> will be known in later game instances, and <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> will be pointless since the environment is already known to the players. An exception to this is <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, as the challenges in these are to find new hiding places.
<style="H3">Narration Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> in a game can depend on how many different types of endings there are to any present stories. This makes <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> limit the <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> to how many different outcomes they can produce, including just being able to produce one story. In contrasts, <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style> regarding storylines (and not game states as discussed above) can allow <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> from a narration perspective rather than from a game state perspective. While these <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style> in many cases focus upon <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> run by <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> that have <style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style> can also be the source of <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> through having characters with <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> in a game offers players the possibility of enjoying a game beyond a single game session, and often does this through offering <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> between game sessions. When this is due to player being able to contemplate different ways of playing, this leads to <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>.

Although developing <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> can be part of why a game has <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>, having complete <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> can work against the pattern instead. Examples of how can happen is fully understanding <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> without <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> or being able to <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorize</link></style> all choices that are supposed to require <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> (this last example can be avoided through the use of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>).

Since <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> in most cases builds upon not knowing what will happen it can be difficult to combine this pattern with <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style>. This is also a reason why the value of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> may lessen with games that support <style="CurrentLink">Replayability</style> unless many different <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> exist or the structures support different outcomes.
<style="H2">Relations</style>
<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Modulate</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Can Be Instantiated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-gameplay">Asymmetric Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-goals">Asymmetric Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="easter-eggs">Easter Eggs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="near-miss-indicators">Near Miss Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-avatar-proximity">Player-Avatar Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style>
<style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>
<style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>
<style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Modulated By</style>
<style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>
<style="H3">Possible Closure Effects</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Potentially Conflicting With</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quizzes">Quizzes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unknown-goals">Unknown Goals</link></style>
<style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> without <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>
